results.abstract: Survey of older Americans finds 40 percent are working for pay in retirement or plan to after they retire, while equal percentage do volunteer work or plan to; Marc Freedman, president of Civic Ventures, poll sponsor, says poll shows concept of retirement as strictly leisure is outdated, interview; poll finds older adults have hard time finding meaningful volunteer opportunities and feel their skills are not valued (M)

headline.main: Older People Want to Work In Retirement, Survey Finds

results.snippet: A new survey of older Americans has found that 40 percent are working for pay in retirement or plan to after they retire, while an equal percentage do volunteer work or plan to.    Marc Freedman, the president of Civic Ventures, a nonprofit...
results.lead_paragraph: A new survey of older Americans has found that 40 percent are working for pay in retirement or plan to after they retire, while an equal percentage do volunteer work or plan to. Marc Freedman, the president of Civic Ventures, a nonprofit organization in California dedicated to expanding the social contributions of older Americans and the sponsor of the survey, said the poll showed that the concept of retirement as strictly leisure is outdated.

results.snippet: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews...
results.lead_paragraph: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 6. Now Playing ''THE ASTRONAUT'S WIFE,'' starring Johnny Depp and Charlize Theron. Written and directed by Rand Ravich (R, 100 minutes). Stylish direction and the heat generated by these two stars can't outweigh the familiarity of the story line. It concerns an astronaut who returns to Earth behaving a little strangely. And not for nothing does Ms. Theron, as the title character, wear the hairdo seen on Mia Farrow in ''Rosemary's Baby.'' Even creatures in other galaxies can guess what's coming. Still, the visual style suggests that this first-time director might fare better with fresher material. And Mr. Depp holds interest by playing the astronaut as one part NASA, two parts Elvis (Janet Maslin).

results.abstract: Word for Word column quotes entries in San Jose State University contest to compose opening sentence to worst of all possible novels; drawing

headline.main: Word for Word/Novel Beginnings; It's the Best of Times For the Worst Opening Lines

results.snippet: WHEN Snoopy isn't out stalking the Red Baron, he can usually be found atop his doghouse tapping out a novel that invariably begins, ''It was a dark and stormy night.'' What most people don't realize is that those words are actually the first sentence...
results.lead_paragraph: WHEN Snoopy isn't out stalking the Red Baron, he can usually be found atop his doghouse tapping out a novel that invariably begins, ''It was a dark and stormy night.'' What most people don't realize is that those words are actually the first sentence of the 1830 novel ''Paul Clifford'' by the eminent Victorian Sir Edward Bulwer-Lytton. Since 1982, Sir Edward has achieved eponymous infamy as the patron saint of the Bulwer-Lytton Fiction Contest, an annual competition held by the English department of San Jose State University. The challenge is simple: ''to compose the opening sentence to the worst of all possible novels.''

results.abstract: Billy Bean tells of isolation he endured during nine years of professional baseball because he was homosexual and had to keep that secret; believes he would have been ostracized if he came out while playing; is now a restaurant owners in Miami Beach; his story offers rare window into fiercely competitive and hyper-masculinized arena of major team sports; photo (L)

headline.main: A Major League Player's Life Of Isolation and Secret Fear

results.snippet: All-America Billy Bean burst into his 20's consumed by two driving dreams: to play center field in the major leagues and to deny his homosexuality. Eventually he would have to choose between his personal and professional lives.    ''For nine years,''...
results.lead_paragraph: All-America Billy Bean burst into his 20's consumed by two driving dreams: to play center field in the major leagues and to deny his homosexuality. Eventually he would have to choose between his personal and professional lives. ''For nine years,'' Bean said recently, ''I felt as though I had one foot in the major leagues and one on a banana peel.''

results.abstract: Dr Shannon Lucid, biochemist who has spent more time in space than any other woman or any other American, is eager to fly again, three years after her record-breaking stay on Russian space station; any space shuttle trip would do, but long stint aboard new international space station would be even better; she has support of her newly retired husband if and when NASA asks her to make a mission; photo (M)

headline.main: A Veteran Is Longing To Return To Space

results.snippet: She has spent more time in space than any other woman or any other American. Yet three years after her record-breaking stay on the Russian space station Mir, Shannon Lucid yearns to fly again.    Any space shuttle trip would do -- but a long stint...
results.lead_paragraph: She has spent more time in space than any other woman or any other American. Yet three years after her record-breaking stay on the Russian space station Mir, Shannon Lucid yearns to fly again. Any space shuttle trip would do -- but a long stint aboard the new international space station would be even better.

results.abstract: France's mayors vote on a model for a new Marianne, the national symbol, choosing from five beautiful finalists, including two supermodels; critics ask why a woman of intellect and accomplishments rather than her looks could not be Marianne; the new Marianne will join earlier versions from which each mayor selects the statue that will grace his or her city hall; photos (M)

headline.main: France Shops for Another Pretty Face

results.snippet: Early statues show a young woman with a helmet on her head and armor over her breast. Later, Marianne looked virginal in a translucent dress. Brigitte Bardot and Catherine Deneuve have posed for statues of her. Those versions -- replicated in the...
results.lead_paragraph: Early statues show a young woman with a helmet on her head and armor over her breast. Later, Marianne looked virginal in a translucent dress. Brigitte Bardot and Catherine Deneuve have posed for statues of her. Those versions -- replicated in the workshops of the Louvre -- grace city halls across the country. Now a question of monumental importance is sweeping France: As the 21st century dawns, does France need a new pretty face in a skimpy dress as a national symbol? And if so, which one?

results.abstract: Astronauts on International Space Station may get tiny robot helpers to assist them in daily chores and to buzz around their orbiting outpost, monitoring its condition; engineers at National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Ames Research Center are developing small robot buddies that could tag along with astronauts and act as personal assistants; developers envision little round robots about size of softballs, propelled by tiny fans through weightlessness of space station or shuttle, hovering over astronauts' shoulders and responding to voice commands; robot sentries are being considered for work outside space station; they could be used, instead of human space-walker, to inspect exterior of spacecraft; photos (M)

headline.main: Building Robot Aides To Follow Astronauts

results.snippet: Astronauts on the International Space Station may get tiny robot helpers to assist them in daily chores and to buzz around their orbiting outpost, monitoring its condition.    Taking a page from science fiction, engineers at the National Aeronautics...
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts on the International Space Station may get tiny robot helpers to assist them in daily chores and to buzz around their orbiting outpost, monitoring its condition. Taking a page from science fiction, engineers at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Ames Research Center at Moffett Field, Calif., are developing small robot buddies that could tag along with astronauts and act as personal assistants.
